{{Distinguish|University of Dallas}} {{Infobox university |name = {{nowrap|The University of Texas at Dallas}} |image_name = UTDallas Logo.svg <!-- University has requested for us to remove the seal --> |motto = {{lang-la|Disciplina praesidium civitatis}} (Education, the Guardian of Society) |established = 1969 <ref name="40 Years"/> |type = [[State university system|State university]] |president = [[David E. Daniel|David Daniel]] |endowment = [[United States dollar|US $]]$229,176,294 (August 31, 2010)<ref name="University of Texas Dallas Annual Report 2010"/> |provost = B. Hobson Wildenthal<ref name="Provost">{{cite web|url=http://provost.utdallas.edu/home/provost-wildenthal|title=Hobson Wildenthal|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas: Office of the Executive Vice President and Provost|accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> |city = [[Richardson, Texas|Richardson]] |state = [[Texas]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |faculty = 988 (Fall 2010)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ospa/stats/Fall_2010/UTDFacultyFall2010.html|title=Faculty - Fall 2010 Profile|accessdate=2011-07-22|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> |undergrad = 10,648 (Fall 2010)<ref name="Fall 2010 headcount"/> |postgrad = 6,480 (Fall 2010)<ref name="Fall 2010 headcount"/> |doctoral =1,143 (Fall 2010)<ref name="Fall 2010 headcount"/> |students = 18,864 (Fall 2011)<ref name="University Profile - Fall 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ospa/stats/UTDProfile.html|title=University Profile - Fall 2011|accessdate=2011-10-13|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> |campus =[[Urban area|Urban]], approximately {{convert|445|acre|km2|abbr=on|disp=/}}<ref name="Facilities Management"/> |former_names = Graduate Research Center of the Southwest (1961â1967), Southwest Center for Advanced Studies (1967â1969)<ref name="Handbook"/> |nickname = Comets |mascot = [[Temoc]]<ref name="Temoc">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/mascot/|title=Temoc: Mascot of UT Dallas|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=3 May 2010}}</ref> |colors = [[Green (color)|Green]] and [[Orange (color)|Orange]] {{color box|#007E3A}}{{color box|#CD5806}} |affiliations = [[American Southwest Conference]], [[University of Texas System|The University of Texas System]] |website = [http://www.utdallas.edu/ www.utdallas.edu] }} The '''University of Texas at Dallas''', also referred to as '''UT Dallas''' or '''UTD''', is a public [[research university]] in the [[University of Texas System]]. The main campus is in the heart of the [[Richardson, Texas|Richardson]], [[Texas]], [[Telecom Corridor]], {{convert|18|mi|km}} north of [[Downtown Dallas|downtown]] [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]]. The institution, established in 1961 as the Graduate Research Center of the Southwest and later renamed the Southwest Center for Advanced Studies (SCAS), began as a research arm of [[Texas Instruments]]. In 1969 the founders bequeathed SCAS to the State of Texas and [[Preston Smith (governor)|Governor Preston Smith]] signed the bill officially creating the University of Texas at Dallas.
UTD offers over 142 academic programs across its seven schools and hosts more than 50 research centers and institutes. With a number of interdisciplinary degree programs, its curriculum is designed to allow study that crosses traditional disciplinary lines and to enable students to participate in collaborative research labs. Entering freshmen average math and critical reading SAT scores are consistently above 1200 and are among the highest of the public universities in Texas. The [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Foundation]] classifies UT Dallas as a "comprehensive doctoral research university" and a "high research activity institution". Research projects include the areas of space science, bioengineering, cybersecurity, nanotechnology, and behavioral and brain sciences.
UT Dallas owns approximately {{convert|710|acre|km2}} of generally contiguous land in Richardson, Texas consisting of {{convert|445|acre|km2}} for campus development and another {{convert|265|acre|km2}} adjacent to the main campus. From 2007 the university has added or started construction on more than {{convert|1000000|sqft|m2}} of new facilities including the first academic structure in Texas to be rated a [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Platinum facility. In addition to the new facilities a $30-million campus landscape enhancement was completed in late 2010 and the university received a "B-" on the 2011 ''College Sustainability Report Card'', which includes efforts to protect and conserve natural resources.
The school has a Division III athletics program in the [[American Southwest Conference]] and fields 13 intercollegiate teams. Student activities include more than 160 registered organizations and students provided more than 20,000 volunteer hours at community agencies in 2010. The university has a nationally recognized debate team, recruits worldwide for its chess team and the only school in Texas to field teams in all three of the major pre-law competitions. As of the 2010 fall commencement the university had over 68,250 alumni, who have earned more than 74,900 degrees.
==History== ===Establishment=== [[File:Founders Building-1964.jpg|thumb|left|The Laboratory of Earth and Planetary Science, (later named the Founders Building), opened in 1964.]] The UT Dallas founders, [[Eugene McDermott]], [[Cecil Howard Green]] and [[J. Erik Jonsson]], purchased [[Geophysical Service Incorporated]] (GSI) on December 6, 1941, the day before the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. With the increase in defense contracts the General Instrument Division of GSI grew to the point it was reorganized as Texas Instruments, Inc. (TI) in 1951 with GSI a wholly owned subsidiary.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=kso4OUQ0GgoC&pg=PA153&lpg=PA153&dq=The+Graduate+Research+Center+of+the+Southwest&q=The%20Graduate%20Research%20Center%20of%20the%20Southwest|publisher=The MIT Press|date= June 22, 1989|title=Cecil and Ida Green, Philanthropists Extraordinary|isbn=0262192764|pages=153â162|accessdate=2010-07-01}}</ref> Qualified personnel required by TI were not readily available in the [[DallasâFort Worth metroplex|Dallas-Fort Worth area]] because the region's universities did not provide enough graduates with advanced training in engineering and physical sciences. TI was forced to recruit talent from other states during its expansion and the founders observed in 1959 that "To grow industrially, the region must grow academically; it must provide the intellectual atmosphere, which will allow it to compete in the new industries dependent on highly trained and creative minds".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/student/catalog/undergrad10/about.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=History |accessdate=2010-10-14}}</ref> To compensate for this shortage they established the Graduate Research Center of the Southwest in 1961. The institute initially was housed in the Fondren Science Library at [[Southern Methodist University]]. Land for the center was acquired by Jonsson, McDermott, and Green in Richardson in 1962 and the first facility, the Laboratory of Earth and Planetary Science (later named the Founders Building), opened on the grounds of the present-day UTD campus in 1964. The Graduate Research Center of the Southwest was renamed the Southwest Center for Advanced Studies (SCAS) in 1967 and in 1969 the founders transferred the land and assets of SCAS to the State of Texas. On June 13, 1969 Governor Preston Smith signed the bill adding the institution to the University of Texas System and creating the University of Texas at Dallas.<ref name="Handbook">{{cite book|last=Champagne|first=Anthony|title=Handbook of Texas Online: University of Texas at Dallas|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|date=2010-02-22|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/UU/kcu10.html|accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref> In 1969 the school accepted its first students. Physics, biology and geological sciences were the first PhD degrees offered. Francis S. Johnson served as interim president and William B. Hanson was named the director of the Division of Atmospheric and Space Sciences now known as the William B. Hanson Center for Space Sciences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://utd500.utdallas.edu/historyframe.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=William B. Hanson Center for Space Sciences |accessdate=2010-06-03}}</ref>
===Expansion and growth=== [[File:Engineering and Computer Science Complex.jpg|thumb|Engineering and Computer Science Complex]] In July 1971, [[Bryce Jordan]] became the universityâs first president and served until 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/40years/transcripts/jordan.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Bryce Jordan Transcription|accessdate=2010-08-26}}</ref> At that time the campus consisted of only one facility, the Founders Building. During Jordan's 10 year tenure the university's received 275 acres (1.11 km2) of land in 1972 from the [[Hoblitzelle Foundation]] and the campus expanded with the addition of a number of new facilities including the Hoblitzelle Hall, Cecil H. Green Hall, J. Erik Jonsson Hall, Lloyd V. Berkner Hall, the Eugene McDermott Library, a campus bookstore and the Visual Arts Building.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gard|first=Wayne|title=Handbook of Texas Online:TEXAS RESEARCH FOUNDATION|publisher=Texas State Historical Association||url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/snt02|accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/development/donor-report/Donor-Report-Fall-2011.pdf|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Donor Report, Fall 2011|accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref> The [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] granted accreditation to UT Dallas in 1972 and in 1973 the first UT Dallas diplomas were awarded.<ref>{{cite web|title=Southern Association of Colleges and Schools|publisher=[[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]]|url=http://www.sacscoc.org/details.asp?instid=73200|accessdate=2010-06-22}}</ref> Prior to 1975 only graduate students were enrolled. Juniors and seniors were admitted for the first time in 1975 and enrollment increased from 700 in the fall of 1974 to 3,333 in 1975 and by the fall of 1977 to more than 5,300 students.<ref name="Handbook"/> The university's first bachelor's degree was awarded at the school's spring commencement in 1976. The Callier Center for Communication Disorders became part of the University of Texas at Dallas in 1975 as part of the School of Human Development (now the School of Behavioral and Brain Sciences).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/calliercenter/|title =Callier Center for Communication Disorders|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Also in 1975, the [[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Management|School of Management]] opened and has become the university's largest and offers programs at the undergraduate, graduate and executive levels. UT Dallas's first [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] laureate, the late [[Polykarp Kusch]], was a member of the physics faculty from 1972 to 1982. When he retired, the university endowed a program of annual lectures with the theme Concerns of the Lively Mind in his honor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2009/04/09-001.php|title=2009 Kusch Lecture To Showcase Mission to Mars|accessdate=2010-05-31|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> Robert H. Rutford, an Antarctic explorer recognized with the naming of the [[Rutford Ice Stream]] and [[Mount Rutford]] in Antarctica, became the second president of UT Dallas in May 1982.<ref name="Antarctic Peak named for Robert Rutford"/> Rutford served as head of the university until 1994. During his tenure as president, the university secured approval for a school of engineering, added freshmen and sophomores to its student body and built the first on-campus housing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/create/print.html|title=Printable Timeline|accessdate=2011-01-29|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> UT Dallas school of engineering opened in 1986 due to the efforts of business, community and education leaders. [[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science|The Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science]] is now the second-largest school at the university. By its 20th anniversary, in 1989, enrollment at UT Dallas topped 8,000.<ref name ="40_Years">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/40years/print.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=40 Years|accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> In 1990, the Texas Legislature authorized the university to admit freshman and sophomore students.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/style/campus-life-u-of-texas-at-dallas-something-brand-new-on-campus-freshmen.html|newspaper=The New York Times|title=Campus Life U. of Texas Dallas|accessdate=2010-06-02 | date=1990-09-02}}</ref> Franklyn Jenifer became the third president of UT Dallas in 1994 and served until 2005. Under Jenifer, UT Dallas's enrollment increased from less than 8,500 to nearly 14,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2003/jenifer.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Franklyn Jenifer|accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref>
===Recent history=== [[File:UT Dallas School of Management.jpg|left|thumb|School of Management]] In the fall of 2001 Ray Baughman and Anvar Zakhidov left [[Honeywell International]] to establish the UT Dallas NanoTech Institute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2003/zakhidovaward.html|title=Profile Anvar Zakhidov|accessdate=2010-07-04|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> With a donation in 2001 from Jim Von Ehr of $3.5 million and the 2002 appointment of the late [[Alan MacDiarmid]] (April 14, 1927 â February 7, 2007), UTD's second Nobel laureate, the institute has grown and is now the Alan G. MacDiarmid NanoTech Institute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nanotech.utdallas.edu/about/index.html|title=UTD NanoTech Institute|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zyvex.com/AboutUs/background.html|title=Zyvex Timeline|publisher=Zyvex|accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> The addition of new facilities continued with the Engineering and Computer Science South Building, a three-story {{convert|152000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} add-on to the university's existing engineering facility in August 2002 and in the fall of 2003 the {{convert|204000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} School of Management building opened and featured 29 classrooms, two computer labs, and a 350-seat auditorium.<ref name="Delivering the UT Dallas Swagger">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/businessaffairs/bulletin/|title=Delivering the UT Dallas Swagger|date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-04-27 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref name="Building Projects to Change Look, Feel of UT Dallas">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2008/10/20-001.php|title=Building Projects to Change Look, Feel of UT Dallas|date=2008-10-20 |accessdate=2010-04-29|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> In June 2005, [[David E. Daniel]] became the fourth president of the University of Texas at Dallas and had served on the faculty at UT Austin and was the Dean of Engineering at the [[University of Illinois]] from 2001 to 2005. He has continued the expansion of the campus with the Natural Science and Engineering Research Laboratory, a four-story {{convert|192000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} research facility, completed in December 2006, the [[Center for BrainHealth]], near [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center|the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center]], dedicated in January 2007 and almost {{convert|600000|sqft|m2|}} of new facilities added from 2007 to 2010.<ref name="Building Projects to Change Look, Feel of UT Dallas"/><ref name="Texas Icon H. Ross Perot highlights Dedication of UTDâs Natural Science & Engineering Research Laboratory">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2007/0605001.html|title=Texas Icon H. Ross Perot highlights Dedication of UTD's Natural Science & Engineering Research Laboratory|accessdate=2008-05-03 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref name="brainhealth.utdallas">{{cite web|url=http://www.brainhealth.utdallas.edu/|title =Center for BrainHealth|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-08-17}}</ref> In 2009 UT Dallas marked its 40 years as a Texas public university and 20 years of freshman enrollment in the university.<ref name ="40_Years"/>
==Academics== ===Student body===
In fall 2010, UTD had a total of 17,128 students enrolled consisting of 10,648 undergraduates students and 6,480 postgraduates students, which includes 1,143 doctoral students.<ref name="Fall 2010 headcount">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ospa/stats/Fall_2010/UTDFall2010Enrollment.html|title=Fall 2010 headcount|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-12-21}}</ref> Relative to most universities in the United States, the school is unusual because it has more males, 56%, than females. The 2010 demographic ethnicity at the school was White American 44%, Asian-American 18%, International 16%, Hispanic 11%, and African-American 6%. Top undergraduate majors are Business Administration, Biology, Accounting & Information Management, Psychology, Electrical Engineering, Arts & Technology, and Computer Science. The top graduate programs are Business Administration, Accounting & Information Management, Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, Humanities, Finance, Information Technology & Management, and Communication Disorders.<ref name="University Profile Fall 2010">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ospa/stats/UTDProfile.html| title=University Profile Fall 2010|publisher=UT Dallas Office of Strategic Planning and Analysis|accessdate=2010-10-05}}</ref> The ''U.S. News & World Report's'' 2012 edition of Best Colleges classified UTD's admission process as "more selective" with an acceptance rate of 49.9%.<ref name="U.S. News & World Report's 2012 edition of Best Colleges national universities"/> In the fall 2011-12 academic year 1,786 freshmen enrolled of which, 39% had finished in the top 10% of their class, 74% in the top quarter and 52 are [[National Merit Scholars]]. Entering freshmen average math and critical reading SAT scores are consistently above 1200, (1248 for fall 2011), and are among the highest of the public universities in Texas.<ref name="Growing Excellence, One Student at a Time">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/president/viewpoint/2011/10/|title=Growing Excellence, One Student at a Time|accessdate=2011-10-26|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref name="State of The University 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/president/state-of-the-university-2010.html|title=State of The University 2010|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-11-03}}</ref> For 2010 the middle 50% of the freshmen had average scores as follows: in critical reading, 540â670, math, 590â700, and in writing 530â650.<ref name="CollegeBoard SAT scores">{{cite web|url=http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=2518&profileId=6|title=CollegeBoard SAT scores|publisher=The College Board|accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> The freshman-to-sophomore retention rate from 2009 to 2010 was 85 percent.<ref name="Common Data Set 2010-11">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ospa/stats/documents/CDS2010-11.pdf|title=Common Data Set 2010-11|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-01-14}}</ref> For the spring 2011 commencement the university granted 989 graduate and PhD degrees and 1,166 undergraduates degrees. This brought the number of degrees granted by the university to more than 74,900 and over 68,250 alumni.<ref name="Nearly 1900 to Receive Diplomas in Fall Graduation">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/12/16-7731_Nearly-1900-to-Receive-Diplomas-in-Fall-Graduation_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|title=Nearly 1900 to Receive Diplomas in Fall Graduation|accessdate=2010-12-15}}</ref><ref name="UT Dallas to Celebrate More Than 2,100 New Grads">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/5/12-10771_UT-Dallas-to-Celebrate-More-Than-2100-New-Grads_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|title=UT Dallas to Celebrate More Than 2,100 New Grads|accessdate=2011-05-13}}</ref>
===Rankings=== {| class="infobox" style="width: 22em; font-size: 75%; text-align:left;" ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | University rankings (overall) |- | '''''[[Academic Ranking of World Universities|ARWU]]''''' World<ref name="Academic Ranking of World Universities - 2011">{{cite web|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities â 2011|publisher=Shanghai Jiao Tong University|accessdate=2011-08-14|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Institution.jsp?param=The%20University%20of%20Texas%20at%20Dallas}}</ref> | 301â400 |- | '''''[[Academic Ranking of World Universities|ARWU]]''''' National<ref name="Academic Ranking of World Universities - 2011"/> | 111â137 |- | '''''[[U.S. News & World Report|USNWR]]''''' National University<ref name="U.S. News & World Report's 2012 edition of Best Colleges national universities">{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/richardson-tx/university-of-texas-dallas-9741|work= Best Colleges 2012|title=U.S. News & World Report's 2012 edition of Best Colleges national universities|accessdate=2011-09-13 |publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref> | 143 |- | '''''[[The Washington Monthly|WM]]''''' National University<ref name="The Washington Monthly 2011 annual college and university rankings">{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings_2011/national_university_rank.php|work=Washington Monthly's 2011 national universities rankings|title=The Washington Monthly 2011 annual college and university rankings |accessdate=2011-08-30|publisher=The Washington Monthly}}</ref> | 222 |}
The ''[[U.S. News and World Report|U.S. News & World Report's]]'' 2012 edition of Best Colleges categorized the University of Texas at Dallas as a "Tier 1" national university, ranked 143 overall, 73 in their national public school rankings and 3rd among Texas public universities.<ref name="U.S. News & World Report's 2012 edition of Best Colleges national universities"/><ref name=U.S.>{{cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-universities/top-public/page+4|title=U.S. News & World Report's 2012 edition of best public colleges and universities|accessdate=2011-09-14 |publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref> The 2011 [[Academic Ranking of World Universities|Shanghai Jiao Tong Rankings]] placed UTD at 301â400 worldwide and 111â137 national rank. They also ranked UT Dallas Social Sciences at 52â75 worldwide and Economics / Business at 44 worldwide.<ref name="Academic Ranking of World Universities - 2011"/> ''[[The Washington Monthly]]'' 2011 annual college and university rankings placed UTD at 222.<ref name="The Washington Monthly 2011 annual college and university rankings"/> [[Kiplinger|''Kiplinger's'']] Personal Finance magazine, 100 Best Values in Public Colleges 2011, ranked UTD at 54th in value for in state residents and 67th for out of state students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kiplinger.com/tools/colleges/|work=The Top 100 At a Glance|title=Kiplinger top 100|accessdate=2011-01-04|publisher=Kiplinger }}</ref>
UTD's undergraduate business programs ranked 81st overall and 39th among public university business schools in the U.S. according to ''[[BusinessWeek]]'s'' 2010 rankings and ranked 30th in overall student satisfaction<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bx.businessweek.com/business-school-rankings/view?url=http%3A%2F%2Fc.moreover.com%2Fclick%2Fhere.pl%3Fr2600089761%26f%3D9791|newspaper=Bloomberg BusinessWeek|title =Businessweek undergrad business|accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> The 2010 ''Bloomberg BusinessWeek'' public universities rankings of undergraduate programs by specialty placed the UTD school of management 10th in both accounting and business law, 1st in teaching of quantitative methods, 3rd in teaching of calculus and sustainability concepts, 6th in financial management, 7th in ethics and 9th in corporate strategy course work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/10/22-6511_School-of-Management-Excels-in-Undergrad-Rankings_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=School of Management Excels in Undergrad Rankings|accessdate=2010-10-22}}</ref>
The ''U.S. News and World Report'''s, "America's Best Graduate Schools 2012", ranks the Full-Time MBA program among the top 40 in the nation and 17 among public universities in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/3/22-9561_MBA-Programs-Ranked-in-Public-University-Top-20_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=MBA Programs Ranked in Public University Top 20|accessdate=2011-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/mba-rankings/page+2|title = MBA News Top 50 |work=Best Business Schools Ranked in 2011|date=2011-03-17|accessdate=2011-03-17|publisher=U.S. News & World Report}}</ref> Additional rankings by the ''U.S. News & World Report's'', "Best Graduate Schools 2012", include, Computer Engineering at 61, Electrical Engineering at 66, Management Information Systems at 18 and the School of Engineering and Computer Science at 70.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/3/16-9441_UT-Dallas-Graduate-Programs-Rise-in-Rankings_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=UT Dallas Graduate Programs Rise in Rankings|accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref>
UT Dallas ranked 10 in the 2011 ''[[The Princeton Review|Princeton Reviewâs]]'' list of the top graduate game design programs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Graduate Game Design Program Ranked in Top 10|url =http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/3/2-9121_Graduate-Game-Design-Program-Ranked-in-Top-10_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-03-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/features/218325/top-10-schools-2-of-5/|title=Princeton Review Top 10 Graduate Game Design Programs|accessdate=2011-03-02|work=The Princeton Review's top 10 grad, undergrad game design schools|publisher=Princeton Review|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/features/218325/top-10-schools-2-of-5/&date=2011-11-30+18:58:02|archivedate=2011-11-30}}</ref> In 2010 the UTD [[Geography]] and [[Geospatial|Geospatial Sciences]] program ranked 16th nationally and first in Texas by ''Academic Analytics'' of Stony Brook, N.Y.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/2/22-1171_Geography-Program-Excels-in-National-Rankings_article.html|title=Geography and Geospatial Sciences program|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-04-29}}</ref> Programs ranked less often than annually include the ''US News & World Report'' ranking of the university's graduate audiology program as 4th in the nation and its graduate speech-pathology program at 12th in the nation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-audiology-schools/rankings|title=Audiology Ranking|accessdate=2010-06-02|date=2008-04-02|work=Audiology Rankings Project|publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-pathology-schools/rankings|title=speech-pathology ranking|accessdate=2010-06-02|date=2008-04-02|work=Speech Pathology Rankings Project |publisher=US News & World Report}}</ref>
===Academic programs=== [[File:UTD Science Learning Center .JPG|thumb|Science Learning Center. The tile exterior represents two patterns: atomic emission spectra of gases, and human DNA.]] {{Main|University of Texas at Dallas academic programs}} For fall 2010, the University of Texas at Dallas offered 142 academic programs across its seven schools including, 51 baccalaureate programs, 62 masters programs and 30 doctoral programs.<ref name="University of Texas Dallas Annual Report 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/president/annualreport/pdf/UTDallas_annual_2010final.pdf|title=University of Texas Dallas Annual Report 2010|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-04-19}}</ref><ref name="The University of Texas at Dallas College Portrait">{{cite web| title = The University of Texas at Dallas College Portrait| url=http://www.collegeportraits.org/TX/UTD|publisher=College Portrait|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> The school also offers 30 undergraduate and graduate certificates.<ref>{{cite web| title = Certificates| url =http://www.utdallas.edu/academics/certificates.html |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-12-28}}</ref> With a number of interdisciplinary degree programs its curriculum is designed to allow study that crosses traditional disciplinary lines and enable students to participate in collaborative research labs.<ref name ="Interdisciplinary degrees">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/admissions/graduate/degrees/interdisciplinary/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Interdisciplinary degrees|accessdate=2010-06-08}}</ref> In 2002 the UTD Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science was the first in the United States to offer an [[Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology|ABET-accredited]] B.S. degree in telecommunications engineering.<ref>{{cite web|title =UTD Wins Approval to Offer 3 New Ph.D. Degrees In Telecom, Software and Computer Engineering|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2002/newphds.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-12-27}}</ref> UTD's Arts and Technology program is Texas's first comprehensive degree designed to merge computer science and engineering with creative arts and the humanities.<ref>{{cite web| title = Arts and Technology| url = http://www.utdallas.edu/ah/programs/atec/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-06-08}}</ref> In 2004 the School of Arts and Humanities introduced the Arts and Technology (ATEC) program with the Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science and in 2008 a complementary major, Emerging Media and Communication (EMAC), was offered.<ref>{{cite web| title =Emerging Media and Communication| url =http://www.utdallas.edu/ah/programs/emac/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-06-08}}</ref> In January 2007 the university offered the first doctoral degree in criminology in Texas. The School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences administers the degree.<ref>{{cite web| title =New Advanced Degrees Establish Texas' First Ph.D. Criminology Program|url =http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2006/criminology-doctorate.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-12-27}}</ref> The Bioengineering department offers MS and PhD degrees in biomedical engineering in conjunction with programs at the [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas]] and the [[University of Texas at Arlington]].<ref>{{cite web| title =Biomedical Engineering| url=http://ecs.utdallas.edu/academics/departmentsandprograms.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-08-22}}</ref> Geospatial Information Sciences is jointly offered with the School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics and with the School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences (EPPS), which administers the degree. The EPPS program was the first from Texas admitted to the University Consortium for Geographic Information Science and offered the first master of science in geospatial information sciences in Texas.<ref>{{cite web| title = University Consortium for Geographic Information Science| url = http://www.utdallas.edu/epps/gis//|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> UT Dallas is the fourth university in the nation to received an accreditation from the [[US Geospatial Intelligence Foundation|United States Geospatial Intelligence Foundation]] (USGIF) for a Geospatial Intelligence certificate.<ref name ="Geospatial Intelligence certificate">{{cite web|url=http://usgif.org/education/accreditation|publisher= United States Geospatial Intelligence Foundation|title=Geospatial Intelligence certificate|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
{| style="border:1px solid #ddd; background:#fefefe; padding:3px; margin:0;" | <span style="font-size:116%;"></span> *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Arts and Humanities|School of Arts and Humanities]] *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Behavioral and Brain Sciences|School of Behavioral and Brain Sciences]] *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences|School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences]] | <span style="font-size:116%;"></span> *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science|Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science]] *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Interdisciplinary Studies|School of Interdisciplinary Studies]] *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#Naveen Jindal School of Management|Naveen Jindal School of Management]] | <span style="font-size:116%;"></span> *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics|School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics]] *[[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#Honors|Honors]] |}
===Research=== The 2010 [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education]] classifies UT Dallas as a "comprehensive doctoral research university" and a "high research activity institution".<ref name="Carnegie">{{cite web |url= http://classifications.carnegiefoundation.org/lookup_listings/view_institution.php?unit_id=228787&start_page=institution.php&clq={%22ipug2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22ipgrad2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22enrprofile2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22ugprfile2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22sizeset2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22basic2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22eng2005_ids%22%3A%22%22%2C%22search_string%22%3A%22university+of+texas+dallas%22%2C%22level%22%3A%22%22%2C%22control%22%3A%22%22%2C%22accred%22%3A%22%22%2C%22state%22%3A%22%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22%22%2C%22urbanicity%22%3A%22%22%2C%22womens%22%3A%22%22%2C%22hbcu%22%3A%22%22%2C%22hsi%22%3A%22%22%2C%22tribal%22%3A%22%22%2C%22msi%22%3A%22%22%2C%22landgrant%22%3A%22%22%2C%22coplac%22%3A%22%22%2C%22urban%22%3A%22%22}|title= Carnegie Classifications|publisher=Carnegie Foundation|accessdate= August 19, 2010}}</ref> Research projects include the areas of space science, bioengineering, cybersecurity, nanotechnology, and behavioral and brain sciences. The university has more than 50 research centers and institutes and the UTD Office of Technology Commercialization, a technology transfer center, serves as the bridge between laboratory research and commercial development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/otc/|title=Office of Technology Commercialization|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref><ref name="Research Centers and Institutes">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/research/centers.html|title=Research Centers and Institutes|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-06-19}}</ref> For the fiscal year ending August 2011, UTD's research expenditures totaled $93,894,309.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/president/state-of-the-university-2011.html|title=State of The University 2011|accessdate=2011-11-10|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
[[File:221588main CNOFSmodel HI.jpg|thumb|Scale model of the [[C/NOFS]] probe. NASA's CINDI instrument is installed on C/NOFS.]] Space science research has been a hallmark of the university since its inception in 1964. The William B. Hanson Center for Space Studies (CSS), affiliated with the Department of Physics, conducts research in space [[plasma physics]]. It has its roots in the Earth and Planetary Sciences Laboratory of the university's predecessor. The center also conducts a NASA-sponsored mission, [[CINDI|Coupled Ion-Neutral Dynamics Investigation (CINDI)]], which was launched in April 2008 in cooperation with the United States Air Force.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2008/04/24-002.php |title=UT Dallas Professor's Experiment Blasts into Space |publisher=UT Dallas News Center |accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref> CINDI, which is part of the payload for the [[C/NOFS|Communication and Navigation Outage Forecast System]] program, seeks to uncover information about the equatorial plasma bubbles that interrupt radio signals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/cindi/index.html|title=CINDI Mission Page|publisher=NASA|accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cindispace.utdallas.edu/|title=CINDI Project Page at UT Dallas|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref> Furthermore, under the leadership of [[John H. Hoffman]], the center designed the [[mass spectrometer]] for the [[Phoenix Mars Lander]] as part of the [[Thermal and Evolved Gas Analyzer]] (TEGA) experiment in cooperation with the [[University of Arizona]].<ref name=marsexp> {{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2008/05/23-001.php|title=Prof Heads to Arizona to Monitor Mars Experiment|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2008-05-25}}</ref>
UT Dallas conducts cybersecurity research in a number of areas including cross-domain information sharing, data security and privacy, data mining for malware detection, geospatial information security, secure social networks, and secure cloud computing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://csrc.utdallas.edu/|title=CYBERSECURITY RESEARCH CENTER|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-12-08}}</ref> The university is designated a National Center of Academic Excellence and a National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Research for the academic years 2008-2013 by the [[National Security Agency]] and [[Department of Homeland Security]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://csepi.utdallas.edu/|title=CyberSecurity and Emergency Preparedness Institute |accessdate=2011-11-13 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
The Alan G. MacDiarmid NanoTech Institute was established in 2001 when Ray Baughman, a pioneering nanotechnologist, became the Robert A. Welch Distinguished Chair in Chemistry and director of the university's NanoTech Institute. In 2007, it was renamed in memory of the late Alan G. MacDiarmid, who shared the 2000 Nobel Prize in chemistry with [[Alan Heeger]] and [[Hideki Shirakawa]]. The NanoTech Institute has produced more than 200 refereed journal articles, 13 of which have been published in [[Science (journal)|''Science'']] or [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']], and given over 300 lectures in the United States and abroad.<ref name="Alan G. MacDiarmid NanoTech Institute Publications">{{cite web |url=http://nanotech.utdallas.edu/publications/index.html|title=Alan G. MacDiarmid NanoTech Institute Publications|accessdate=2010-04-26 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> Ray Baughman was ranked number 30 on the March 2, 2011, Thomson Reuters list of the top 100 materials scientists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/7/8-11621_NanoTech-Director-Makes-List-of-Top-Researchers_article.html|title=NanoTech Director Makes List of Top Researchers|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/misc/Top100MatSci2000-10/|title=Top 100 Materials Scientists|accessdate=2011-07-11 |publisher=Thomson Reuters }}</ref>[[File:NSERL.JPG|left|thumb|Natural Science and Engineering Research Laboratory building]]
The Natural Science and Engineering Research Laboratory (NSERL), a four-story, {{convert|192000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} research facility, was completed in December 2006 after two years of construction. Including [[ISO 14644-1|ISO]] [[Cleanroom#Cleanroom classifications|7]] [[cleanroom]] facilities, the $85 million building provides open floor plans that allows chemists, biologists, nanotechnologists, materials scientists and other specialists to conduct multidisciplinary research. The laboratory provides extensive wet lab, fabrication, instrumentation, and high performance computing facilities to foster biomedical engineering and nano-technology research. The [[Nanoelectronics]] Materials Laboratory, on the fourth floor, includes a system that allows researchers to deposit thin film materials one atomic layer at a time. In May 2011 a $3 millon JEOL ARM200F scanning transmission electron microscope with an atomic resolution of 0.78 [[picometers]], was added to the research laboratory, already home to two transmission electron microscopes.<ref name="Texas Icon H. Ross Perot highlights Dedication of UTDâs Natural Science & Engineering Research Laboratory"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeol.com/PRODUCTS/ElectronOptics/TransmissionElectronMicroscopesTEM/200kV/JEMARM200F/tabid/662/Default.aspx|title=JEM-ARM200F Opens Doors to New Ultra Micro Analysis|publisher=JEOL.Ltd.|accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/3/25-2001_Microscope-to-Further-Bolster-Nanotech-Research_article.html|title=Microscope to Further Bolster Nanotech Research|accessdate=2010-09-06|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
[[File:Outside of bh wiki.jpg|thumbnail|Center for BrainHealth]] The [[Center for BrainHealth]], both its own facility and part of the School of Behavioral and Brain Sciences, is a research institute with clinical interventions focused on brain health. The center is located near the UT Dallas' Callier Center for Communication Disorders and adjacent to the north campus of [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center]] in the city of Dallas. Brain research is concentrated on brain conditions, diseases, and disorders including, Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, autism, dementia, stroke, traumatic brain injury, and working memory.<ref name="brainhealth.utdallas" />
The Callier Center for Communication Disorders became part of the University of Texas at Dallas in 1975 as part of the School of Human Development (now the School of Behavioral and Brain Sciences). Research, at the center, includes the causes, prevention, assessment and treatment of communication disorders and the facilities include laboratories for research in child language development and disorders, autism spectrum disorders, speech production, hearing disorders, neurogenic speech and language, cochlear implants and aural habilitation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/calliercenter/|title =Callier Center for Communication Disorders|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-08-17}}</ref>
Additional ongoing research initiatives at UT Dallas include, researchers overseeing the long-running British Election Study (BES). Harold Clarke, the Ashbel Smith professor of political science in the School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences, and Marianne Stewart, professor of political science are the co-principal investigators for the study, which began in 1964 and is one of the world's oldest continuous political research projects. The other two co-investigators are David Sanders and Paul Whiteley of the [[University of Essex]] in England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bes2009-10.org/|title=UK voting study|accessdate=2010-06-02|publisher=British Election Study}}</ref>
===Scholarship programs=== All freshmen admitted to the university are automatically considered for an Academic Excellence Scholarship Award. Effective for the fall 2012 incoming freshmen class the awards range from $3,000 per year for tuition and mandatory fees up to complete coverage of UT Dallas tuition and mandatory fees plus $3,000 per semester cash stipend to defray the costs of books, supplies and other expenses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oue.utdallas.edu/aes/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Academic Excellence Scholarship |accessdate=2011-11-18}}</ref> The McDermott Scholars Program, established at UT Dallas in 2000, provides full scholarships and unique cultural and civic opportunities to academically talented high school students.<ref name="Eugene McDermott Scholars Program">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/mcdermott/|title=Eugene McDermott Scholars Program|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-05-03}}</ref> UT Dallas is also among only seven universities whose students are eligible for consideration for Terry Scholarships and became part of the program in 2006.<ref name="TerryScholars">{{cite web|title=Terry Scholars|url=http://www.terryfoundation.org/|publisher=The Terry Foundation|accessdate=1 June 2010|date=2010-05-18}}</ref>
==Campus==
The main campus is in the heart of the Richardson, Texas, Telecom Corridor, {{convert|18|mi|km}} north of downtown Dallas, on the boundary of [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas]] and [[Collin County, Texas|Collin]] counties. UT Dallas owns generally contiguous land in Richardson, Texas consisting of approximately {{convert|465|acre|km2}} for campus development and another {{convert|265|acre|km2}} adjacent to the campus.<ref name="Facilities Management">{{cite web|title= Facilities Management|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/facilities/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-10-20}}</ref> UTD's Waterview Science & Technology Center and the Research and Operations Center, a leased building, are adjacent to the main campus, on the west side of Waterview Parkway in the Dallas, Texas city limits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/maps/|title=Campus Map|date=2009-04-29 |accessdate=2010-09-16|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> UTD's Callier Center, 8 buildings, is on {{convert|5.5|acre|km2}} adjacent to the [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center]] in the city of Dallas and nearby the [[Center for BrainHealth]], a single building, on {{convert|3.5|acre|km2}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/maps/callier.html|title=Map of the Callier Center Dallas Campus|date=2011-01-07 |accessdate=2011-01-07|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> The city of Richardson, Texas passed a bond election on May 8, 2010, which allocated $2.8 million in funding for a UT Dallas loop road to connect the roads around campus. The loop road will be designed to help keep traffic contained within the campus, rather than on the cityâs roads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cor.net/Bond/2010Bond.aspx?id=11897|title=City of Richardson Bond Election|date=2010-02-15 |accessdate=2011-09-16|publisher=City of Richardson }}</ref> The ''UTD Mercury'' noted in a February 15, 2011 article that a lack of on-campus parking has been an ongoing problem. Additional parking lots were added in 2010 and 2011. However, due to the continued increase in enrollment, the lack of available parking spaces continues to be a frustrating issue for the students. In November 2011 the UT System Board of Regents approved initial plans for two five-story parking structures. The two structures will increase the Universityâs parking capacity by 1,500 spaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/11/22-14191_Garages-Lot-Expansions-to-Add-Nearly-1700-Parking-_article-wide.html|title=Garages, Lot Expansions to Add Nearly 1,700 Parking Spaces|date=2011-11-21 |accessdate=2011-11-21|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> The university received a "B-" on the 2011 ''College Sustainability Report Card'', which includes efforts to protect and conserve natural resources.<ref name="Sustainable Endowments Institute Report Card">{{cite web | title =College Sustainability Report Card 2011 | publisher =Sustainable Endowments Institute | url =http://www.greenreportcard.org/report-card-2011/schools/university-of-texas-dallas| accessdate = 2011-11-19}}</ref>
===Architecture=== [[File:UT Dallas Student Service Building.JPG|thumb|Student Services building]] Early architecture on the campus exhibits typical characteristics of [[Brutalism]], a popular civic style when the structures were designed and built. In accordance with this style, many of the early buildings are pale, off-white, precast concrete with repetitive structures. Later architecture exhibits late modern or [[Postmodern architecture|postmodern]] features such as bronze glass, bronze aluminum frames, unadorned geometric shapes, unusual surfaces, and unorthodox layouts. This later modern styling is seen in the Engineering and Computer Science building, School of Management, Cecil and Ida Green Center, and Natural Science and Engineering Research Lab facility (sometimes called the Mermaid Building due to its colorful anodized shingles). The Student Services building, completed in 2010, is the first academic structure in Texas to be rated a [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Platinum facility by the [[U.S. Green Building Council|United States Green Building Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/2/10-8711_UT-Dallas-Building-Awarded-Highest-Green-Status_article.html|title=UT Dallas Building Awarded Highest Green Status|accessdate=2011-02-08|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> To provide protection from inclement weather and extreme temperatures, many of the buildings on campus are connected by a series of elevated indoor walking paths also referred to as [[skyway]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/pardonourprogress/images/Indoor-Walking-Path-Map.pdf|title=Indoor Walking Path|accessdate=2011-07-25|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
===Landscape Architecture=== [[File:UTD mall.JPG|thumb|left|Campus mall]] A 30-million dollar Campus Landscape Enhancement Project, largely funded by Margaret McDermott the wife of UTD founder Eugene McDermott (1899-1973), was started in October 2008 and completed in late 2010. The project encompassed all aspects of landscape architecture from campus identity to pedestrian strategies, future growth patterns, sustainability and establishing a campus core. The project included the reforestation of the main entry drive with more than 5,000 native trees. Each tree hand-picked and individually arranged by the landscape architect after careful study of native stands in Texas, which includes the commitment to a [[Riparian zone|riparian]] corridor consisting of a densely planted natural creek bed along the central entry median to the campus [[Avenue (landscape)|AllÃ©e]]. The main mall or 'AllÃ©e' includes 116 hand-picked columnar 'Claudia Wannamaker' Magnolias alongside five reflecting pools and four human-scale chess boards to represent the national and international achievements of the school's chess team. At the northern terminus of the AllÃ©e and between the McDermott Library and the Student Union is a pavilion-sized plaza. The plaza includes a granite fountain complete with mist column, an overhead trellis to be eventually covered in [[wisteria]] vines and a temperature-modifying shade structure design. The landscape architecture firm of [[Peter Walker (architect)|Peter Walker and Partners]] (PWP) was the prime consultant for the project. PWP is recognized for design of the {{convert|1000|acre|km2|adj=on}} Millennium Parklands in Sydney, Australia for the 2000 Summer Olympics and currently the World Trade Center Memorial at Ground Zero in Manhattan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/facilities/files/CLEP-Executive-Summary-Nov-2010.pdf|title=Campus Landscape Enhancement Project |accessdate=2011-01-01|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/enhance/downloads/enhancement-facts.pdf|title=Campus Enhancement Facts|date=2007-04-16|accessdate=2010-09-17 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/president/viewpoint/2010/10/|title=President Viewpoint 2010|accessdate=2011-01-01|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
===Building plans=== [[File:UTD Visitor Center.jpg|thumb|UTD Visitor Center]] The university added almost {{convert|600000|sqft|m2}} of new facilities from 2007 through 2010.<ref name="Delivering the UT Dallas Swagger"/> The facilities include a {{convert|74000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Science Learning Center (SLC), a renovation and expansion of Founders Hall, a {{convert|74000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Student Services Building and a {{convert|148000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} 400-bed Residence Hall South.<ref name="Building Projects to Change Look, Feel of UT Dallas"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/businessaffairs/bulletin/construction.php5|title=Business Affairs Bulletin|accessdate=2010-04-27|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> More than {{convert|600000|sqft|m2}} of additional facilities are planned for completion from 2011 through 2013. A second, $31 million {{convert|150000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, freshman Residence Hall North was started in July 2010 and officially completed on June 27, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/6/14-3951_Heavy-Demand-Spurs-Approval-of-2nd-Residence-Hall_article.html|title=-Approval of 2nd-Residence-Hall| date=2010-06-14 |accessdate=2010-06-14|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> A $9.5 million {{convert|33000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, University Bookstore and Visitor Center was started in January 2011 and completed in July 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/1/19-8171_Visitor-Center-New-Edition-of-Bookstore-Ready-to-G_article-wide.html|title=New Bookstore, Visitor Center to Arrive Ahead of Schedule|date=2011-01-18 |accessdate=2011-01-18|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> A 3rd, $31 million {{convert|151000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, freshmen Residence Hall has been approved and planned for occupancy by fall 2012.<ref name="University Unveils Plans for 3rd Residence Hall">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/7/28-11851_University-Unveils-Plans-for-3rd-Residence-Hall_article-wide.html|title=University Unveils Plans for 3rd Residence Hall| date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2011-07-28|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> Groundbreaking for a $60 million, {{convert|157920|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, Arts and Technology Building was held on September 28, 2011 with a projected completion date of fall 2013. Spaces include 2,150 classroom seats and 50 faculty offices, a 1200 seat auditorium, 2D drawing and painting art studios, 3D art studios, and an exterior video screen showcasing ATEC projects and other visual arts. For the design UT Dallas chose [[Studios Architecture]]âthe firm that designed Google Headquarters in Mountain View, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/5/13-10801_UT-Regents-Approve-Plans-to-Build-ATEC-a-New-Home_article.html|title=UT Regents Approve Plans to Build ATEC a New Home|date=2011-05-13|accessdate=2011-05-13|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/calendar/event.php?id=1220213201|title=Groundbreaking for the Arts and Technology Building|date=2011-09-25|accessdate=2011-09-27|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/facilities/files/Arts-Technology-Facility-Phase-A1-Oct-2011.pdf|title=Arts and Technology Facility - Phase A1|accessdate=2011-11-13|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> A new Visual Arts Studio that will include areas for design, drawing, painting, sculpture studios and exhibition space is projected to start in June 2012 with a completion date in the summer of 2013. The $10 million, {{convert|25000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} facility will include space for advanced studio work for the Masters in Fine Arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/facilities/files/ATEC-B-Executive-Summary-Sept-20101.pdf|title=Visual Arts Studio|date=2010-06-11|accessdate=2010-09-28|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> In October 2011 the University of Texas System Board of Regents approved a $25 million funding program to build a {{convert|100000|sqft|m2}} addition to the Naveen Jindal School of Management with an estimated completion date in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/10/7-13041__article-wide.html|title=New Names for Management School, Management Honors Program Recognize Record Alumni Gifts|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-10-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/facilities/files/School-of-Management-Phase-II-Oct-2011.pdf|title=School of Management Phase II|accessdate=2011-11-13|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> In November 2011 the UT System Board of Regents has approved initial plans for a fourth, 600 bed residential facility, including a dining hall with seating for 800, a recreation center and a parking garage. Work on the $75 million, {{convert|285000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, facility is expected to begin in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/11/22-14231_4th-Residence-Hall-to-Bring-Amenities-to-Students-_article-wide.html|title=4th Residence Hall to Bring Amenities to Studentsâ Doorsteps|date=2011-10-20 |accessdate=2011-10-20|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
==Student life== ===Activities=== [[File:UTD Activity Center.JPG|thumb|left|Activity Center]] The University of Texas at Dallas has more than 160 registered student organizations, 15 national Greek-letter fraternities and sororities and students provided more than 20,000 volunteer hours at community agencies in 2009.<ref name="UT Dallas Fast Facts">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/enhance/utd-facts.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=UT Dallas Fast Facts|accessdate=2010-12-16}}</ref> UTD's {{convert|89000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Activity Center contains a state-of-the-art fitness center, racquetball courts, squash courts, basketball courts, a multi-purpose room, and indoor swimming pool. Also available are sand volleyball courts, soccer fields, tennis courts, softball fields, baseball fields and a [[disc golf]] course. The universityâs Club Sports Program consists of student organizations that promote common sports and recreation interests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/recsports/index.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Activity Center|accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
The UT Dallas Debate Team was established in the fall of 1996 and won the [[Cross Examination Debate Association|Cross Examination Debate Association's]] "Brady Lee Garrison Newcomer Sweepstakes Award" in spring 1997. UTD first qualified a team for the [[National Debate Tournament]] in 2004 and has qualified each year since. In 2004 the team also hosted its first annual "Fear and Loathing" tournament, the largest annual regular season college tournament in the region with more than 325 participants, coaches, and judges in attendance. The UT Dallas debate squad finished its 2009â10 season as the only organization in the country to advance a team to the quarterfinals in both the [[National Debate Tournament|64th Annual National Debate Tournament]] and the Cross Examination Debate Association, held in March 2010 at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref name="debate 2009-10 season">{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/4/6-2271_Debaters-Make-Solid-Showing-at-National-Contests_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=debate 2009â10 season|accessdate=2010-05-13}}</ref> In March 2011, UT Dallas was host to the 65th National Debate Tournament and placed 9th out of 78 teams.<ref >{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/4/11-10111_Debate-Team-Finishes-National-Tourney-in-Top-10_article-wide.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Debate Team Finishes National Tourney in Top 10|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref>
The school fields teams in the major pre-law competitions: Moot Court, Mock Trial and Mediation. UT Dallas is the only Texas university to compete in all three and the law schools acceptance rate for UTD pre-law graduates was 86% in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oue.utdallas.edu/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Undergraduate Education at UT Dallas|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> In November 2009, the UT Dallas team won the National Mediation Tournament championship in the advocate/client division. The tournament was held at the [[John Marshall Law School (Chicago)|John Marshall Law School in Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2009/11/20-003.php|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Indisputably Excellent: Mediation Teams Win Big|accessdate=2010-12-21}}</ref> In 2010, UTD students again placed first and second in the advocate/client division to win the Dan Stamatelos National Trophy for Advocacy. The tournament was held at the [[Drake University Law School]] and UT Dallas was the only school to place two teams to the final rounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/12/16-7721_Its-Agreed-Mediation-Team-is-Tops-in-Nation-Again_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Mediation Team is Tops in Nation Again|accessdate=2010-12-21}}</ref> UTD received first, second and fourth place at the November 2010, South Central Regional Moot Court Championships. The [[University of Arkansas at Little Rock School of Law|University of Arkansas at Little Rock's, William H. Bowen School of Law]] was host to the 32 teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.ualr.edu/news/showstory.asp?NID=263|publisher=University of Arkansas at Little Rock|title=Winners Announced for South Central Regional Moot Court Championships |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref>
[[File:UT Dallas human-scale chessboards.JPG|thumb|Human-scale chess boards]] UTD's recent campus enhancement project included four human-scale chess boards to represent the national and international achievements of the school's chess team. The internationally ranked UT Dallas chess team was launched in 1996 under the direction of Timothy Redman, a two-time president of the U.S. Chess Federation and professor of literary studies in UTDâs School of Arts and Humanities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2006/redman-resigns-chess.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=U. T. Dallas' Tim Redman Recognized By United States Chess Federation|accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> The university recruits worldwide for its chess team and 18 [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] and [[International Masters]] have played for UT Dallas from 1996 to 2010. UT Dallas offers chess scholarships to qualified student-players and several full four-year tuition tournament-based scholarships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/chess/chess-team/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=The UT Dallas Chess Team|accessdate=2010-08-28}}</ref> UT Dallas has taken first place in eight of its 12 appearances at the Texas State College Championship and the UTD chess team has won or tied for first place in the Southwest Collegiate Championship for the years 2003, 2004, 2006, 2007, 2008 and 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/11/18-7211_Chess-Team-Edges-Out-Rivals-in-State-Championship_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Chess Team Edges Out Rivals in State Championship|accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/chess/chess-team/accomplishments.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=UT Dallas Chess Team Accomplishments|accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref> The UTD chess team has won the Transatlantic Cup in 2007, 2008, 2009 and tied the 2011 match with the [[University of Belgrade]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/11/8-13851_Chess-Team-Battles-to-a-Draw-in-Trans-Atlantic-Riv_article-wide.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Chess Team Battles to a Draw in Trans-Atlantic Rivalry|accessdate=2011-11-08}}</ref> As of 2010, UTD's chess players have won or tied eight of the last eleven [[Pan American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship]] titles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alchess.com/chess/10/usopen/|publisher=The United States Chess Federation|title=111th U.S. Open Chess Championship|accessdate=2010-08-22}}</ref> UT Dallas won first place with a perfect 6-0 score and the Best All-Around Womenâs Team in the December 2010 Pan American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panamerican.wichessacademy.com/intercollegiate-team-championships/|publisher=Wisconsin Academy of Chess |title=2010 Pan American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship|accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/1/5-7881_UT-Dallas-Chess-Team-Topples-Competition_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=UT Dallas Chess Team Topples Competition|accessdate=2011-01-04}}</ref> The UT Dallas chess team has competed in each consecutive Final Four of Chess tournaments starting in 2001 though 2011, winning or tying for first place five times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/4/4-9951_Chess-Team-Finishes-2nd-in-Hard-Fought-Final-Four_article.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=Chess Team Finishes 2nd in Hard-Fought Final Four|accessdate=2011-04-04}}</ref>
===Student media=== The ''UTD Mercury'' is the official student newspaper of the University of Texas at Dallas since 1980. They publish 7,000 copies every other Monday during the fall and spring semesters, and every third Monday during the summer. It is distributed free around campus or at the UTD newsroom in the Student Union. The ''UTD Mercury'' also publishes online at utdmercury.com. In April 2011, ''the Mercury'' won 12 awards at the 101st annual Texas Intercollegiate Press Association IPA convention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/5/3-10571_The-News-is-Good-for-Student-Media-at-Awards-Event_article.html|title=The News is Good for Student Media at Awards Event|publisher =The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref> In 2004, another student newspaper named ''A Modest Proposal'' (''AMP'') was formed. In contrast to The ''UTD Mercury'', which is almost all news articles, ''AMP'' features mostly editorial content. ''AMP'' is published once a month, eight times a year. Any student, faculty, or staff of UTD can contribute to the paper. Copies of ''AMP'' are available for free at the first of each month around the campus, and can also be downloaded in PDF format from their website.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://amp.utdallas.edu/about/ | title=About ''A Modest Proposal''|publisher=A Modest Proposal|accessdate=2007-10-06}}</ref> ''[[Radio UTD]]'', the university's student-run, internet-only, radio station offers streaming music 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and broadcasts UTD sports games. Radio UTD has also been featured on XM Satellite Radio Channel 43 ([[XMU (XM)|XMU]]) on The Student Exchange Program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2008/02/25-001.php |title=Radio UTD to Beam Show on XM Satellite Station |accessdate=2008-04-17 |date=2008-02-25 |publisher=UT Dallas News Center}}</ref> The radio station was nominated for three college radio awards at the 2010 [[College Music Journal]] annual Music Marathon and Festival. The nominations were for the following categories, Best Use of the Internet, Best Use of Limited Resources and Station of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiosurvivor.com/2010/10/14/2010-cmj-music-marathon-preview-and-college-radio-awards-nominees/|title=2010 CMJ Music Marathon Preview and College Radio Awards Nominees|publisher =Radio Survivor|accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> In 2009, UTD TV, an internet-based campus TV station, was founded and launched by students. Still in its infancy, it has already webcast a range of student-interest programs from campus news and amusing serial stories to student affairs coverage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.utdallas.edu/ |title=TV utdallas.edu|publisher =The University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2010-04-30}}</ref>
===Residential housing=== [[File:ResidenceHall.jpg|left|thumb|UTD Residence Hall South]]
Total on-campus housing capacity for the 2011-2012 academic year was 4,754 beds, which consisted of 1,237 apartments (3,954 beds) and two 400-bed residential halls for freshmen.<ref name="UTD Housing">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/housing/|title=Housing at UT Dallas|date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-04-27 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> The apartments are split into two areas. Buildings 1â37, 696 units, are owned by the Utley Foundation and is a self-managing entity under the name Waterview Park Apartments, LLC.<ref name="Waterview Park Apartments">{{cite web |url= http://www.waterviewparkapts.com/about-us.aspx|title=Waterview Park Apartments|date=2010-05-10 |accessdate=2010-05-10 |publisher=Waterview Park Apartments, LLC..}}</ref> Buildings 38â67, 541 units, and the residence halls are owned by the university and privately managed by [[American Campus Communities]] under the name University Village. Apartment floor plans vary from 1-bedroom to 4-bedroom units and amenities include swimming pools, volleyball courts, outdoor grills, and study centers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/housing/uv/ |title=University Village|date=2009-08-20 |accessdate=2010-05-09 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> According to a ''UTD Mercury'' September 18, 2011 article both graduate and upperclassman housing continues to be in short supply due to the increase in enrollment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.utdmercury.com/2011/08/28/overcrowded-housing|newspaper=The UTD Mercury|title=Overcrowed Housing|accessdate=2011-09-18}}</ref> During the 2010 fall semester, 64 percent of new freshmen lived on campus and 23 percent of undergraduates lived in on-campus housing.<ref name="Common Data Set 2010-11"/>
[[File:UT Dallas Apartments.JPG|thumb|Waterview Park Apartments]] On August 12, 2009 a {{convert|148000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} residence hall, (Residence Hall South), opened providing housing for 384 full-time freshmen residents and 16 peer advisers. The new residence hall offers living learning environments that group students with similar interests and majors. The building includes a mix of three-bedroom, single-bath suites for freshmen and one-bedroom, one-bath units for peer advisers. On each wing and each floor are several communal study areas and the ground floor features a {{convert|1800|sqft|m2|sing=on}} glass-enclosed rotunda with pool and ping-pong tables, large-screen televisions, couches and chairs.<ref name="ResHall">{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2008/04/15-003.php |title=Event to Celebrate Residence Hall's Construction |date=2008-04-15 |accessdate=2008-11-03 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> A 2nd, {{convert|150000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} residence hall, (Residence Hall North), was officially completed June 27, 2011 and a 3rd freshmen residence hall adjacent to the two existing halls has been approved and planned for occupancy by fall 2012.<ref name="University Unveils Plans for 3rd Residence Hall"/> In November 2011 the UT System Board of Regents has approved initial plans for a fourth, 600 bed residential facility, including a dining hall with seating for 800, a recreation center and a parking garage. Work on the $75 million, {{convert|285000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}, facility is expected to begin in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2011/11/22-14231_4th-Residence-Hall-to-Bring-Amenities-to-Students-_article-wide.html|title=4th Residence Hall to Bring Amenities to Studentsâ Doorsteps|date=2011-10-20 |accessdate=2011-10-20|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
===Dining on campus=== Students have a selection of food sources on campus. The Student Union building houses The Pub and the Comet Cafe food court which includes a [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]], [[Chick-fil-A]], Chefâs Table and [[Papa John's]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dineoncampus.com/utdallasdining/show.cfm?cmd=menus|title=Where to Eat at UT Dallas|date=2011-02-08 |accessdate=2011-02-08|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> The first dining hall on campus opened on August 12, 2009 in conjunction with the opening of the first residence hall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2009/09/08-003.php|title=New Halls Having an Official Housewarming Party|date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2009-08-20 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> The {{convert|28000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} dining hall provides seating for more than 400 and offers a variety of options including vegetarian and vegan options, home-style entrees, grilled-to-order items, pizzas and pasta, made-to-order omelets and traditional Tex-Mex cuisine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2009/08/10-001.php |title=Dinner is Served: New Meal Plans, Dining Hall Set to Go |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2009-08-20 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> All first-year students living on campus are required to purchase a meal plan; meal plans are optional for all other students who live on campus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dineoncampus.com/utdallasdining/?cmd=_mealPlansFAQs|title=First-Year Students Meal Plans|date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-08-19|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
===Traditions=== [[File:UT Dallas Love Jack.jpg|thumb|upright|Love Jack]] Some of the traditions that give UT Dallas its distinctive flavor are Homecoming, Annual Oozeball Tournament, Ceremonial Mace, Legacy Lane, Welcome Week, Sounds of Class, Family Day, Splatterbeat and Cecil Greenâs Head. Cecil Green helped found the University of Texas at Dallas and outside Green Hall there is a bronze bust of Cecil Green. Rubbing Greenâs head for good luck has become a tradition for many students on their way to exams or presentations. Holiday Sing is one of the oldest tradition on campus, the annual Holiday Sing started in 1976 and is hosted by the School of Arts and Humanities during the month of December. In front of the Erik Jonsson Academic Center is the sculpture ''Jack'', created in 1971 by artist [[Jim Love (artist)| Jim Love]] (1927 - 2005). Margaret McDermott, wife of UTD founder Eugene McDermott (1899-1973), presented the sculpture to the university in 1976. The sculpture is affectionately known on campus as the Love Jack. Recently added is the Spirit Rock on the mall between the Jonsson and Green buildings. Students and organizations are allowed to paint whatever they like on the rock, provided it conforms to rules of student conduct.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/traditions/|title=Traditions|date=2011-04-28 |accessdate=2011-09-16|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/student/sg/spiritrock/|title=Spirit Rock|date=2009-01-14|accessdate=2011-09-16|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref>
==Athletics== The University of Texas at Dallas athletics program started when UTD provisionally joined the [[NCAA Division III]] and the [[American Southwest Conference]] (ASC) in 1998 and was granted full membership in the ASC in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascsports.org/sports/2007/8/15/About%20ASC.aspx|publisher=American Southwest Conference|title=American Southwest Conference|accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> Varsity sports include baseball, basketball, cross country, golf, soccer, softball, tennis, and volleyball.<ref>{{cite web| title =Comet Sports| url =http://cometsports.utdallas.edu/index.aspx|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas| accessdate=2010-07-02}}</ref> In addition to varsity sports, the university's Sport Clubs Programs offers recreational and competitive sport clubs, including inline hockey, fencing, rugby, racquetball, mixed martial arts and soccer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/recsports/club_sports/clubsports.html|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title=The Department of Recreational Sports|accessdate=2011-01-02}}</ref>
===Varsity athletics=== [[File:UTD Comets Logo.jpg|thumb|upright|left|UTD Comets athletics logo]] During the 2002 inaugural season, the men and women's soccer teams competed for conference championships. The women won the 2002 ASC title and UTD ended up hosting the conference tournament as well as the first round of NCAA playoffs in UTD's first year as active members. The success continued in 2003â04 when men's and women's soccer, men's basketball, baseball and softball all advanced to the post-season.<ref name="UT DALLAS ATHLETIC HISTORY">{{cite web|url=http://cometsports.utdallas.edu/sports/2008/6/23/NEWS_0623085408.aspx?tab=utdathletichistory/|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas |title= UT Dallas Athletic History|accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> In 2005, the UTD Athletic Program claimed three ASC Championships: men's soccer and men's basketball as well as a co-championship in women's soccer. The men's soccer and basketball teams advanced to the NCAA Division III national playoffs in their sports. On December 20, 2006 the Comets men's basketball team upset [[University of Texas at Arlington|the University of Texas at Arlington]] Mavericks 78â76 at UT Arlington's [[Texas Hall]] and became the first Division III team to defeat a Division I basketball team during the 2006â2007 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cometsports.utdallas.edu/sports/2008/7/23/MBB_200607.aspx?id=60|title=Unbeaten Comets Upset D1 UT-Arlington December 30, 2006|accessdate=January 10, 2007|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> In 2007, the men's soccer team won the ASC championship, advancing to the NCAA tournament. Having 8 new team players as starters and only 3 veterans, the Comets led by top goal scorers Kevin White from Houston and Mihai Cotet from Braila, Romania led the team to its second ASC Tournament title in history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cometsports.utdallas.edu/sports/2008/7/18/MSOC_07ARCHIVES.aspx?id=34|title=UTD Wins ASC soccer|accessdate=2010-05-08|date=2008-11-08 |publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas }}</ref> The 2007 men's tennis program had a very successful season, beating Division II teams and advancing as far as the ASC Conference final before falling to Hardin-Simmons. The women's volleyball team claimed the 2009 American Southwest Conference championship at the UT Dallas Activity Center. The 25â0, 2009 women's volleyball team was the only undefeated NCAA Division III team in the nation at the time. The womenâs volleyball team won the 2011 ASC East title with an un-defeated home record of 6-0, and a conference record of 14-2.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.utdmercury.com/2011/11/14/lady-comets-wrap-up-asc-east-title/|title=Lady Comets wrap up ASC East title|newspaper=The UTD Mercury|accessdate=2011-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ascsports.org/news/2009/11/7/WVBALL_1107093705.aspx |title=ASC Volleyball Tournament Field Announced |date=2009-11-07 |accessdate=2010-08-09 |publisher=American Southwest Conference}}</ref> The woman's 2009 basketball team won the ASC East Division title, whereas the UTD men's basketball team won the ASC East Division both in 2010 and 2011. For the 2011 season, the Comets men's baseball team finished in second place in the ASC East qualifying for the ASC Tournament for the eighth time in the programâs 10-year history.
==Notable people== [[File:James Reilly.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|Astronaut [[James F. Reilly]]]] {{Main|List of University of Texas at Dallas people}} UT Dallas people includes an Antarctic explorer,<ref name="Antarctic Peak named for Robert Rutford">{{cite web |url=http://www.gsafweb.org/CurrentEvents/mtrutford.html|title=Antarctic Peak named for Robert Rutford|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=The Geological Society of America Foundation}}</ref> an astronaut,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/archive/2005/reilly-talk.html|title=NASA astronaut|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> members of the National Academies,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/about/|title=About UT Dallas|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> a Nobel laureate,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1993/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1993 was awarded to Russell A. Hulse|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=Nobelprize.org}}</ref> a writer and folklorist,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/5/24-3631_Alumnus-Wins-Guggenheim-for-Photography-Research_article.html|title=Alumnus Wins Guggenheim|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> a member of Indiaâs Parliament,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2010/2/26-1391_Alumni-Award-Recipients-and-New-Leadership-Honor-A_article-wide.html|title=Alumni Award Recipients|accessdate=2010-06-10|publisher=The University of Texas at Dallas}}</ref> the founder of the worldâs first molecular nanotechnology company<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zyvex.com/AboutUs/background.html|title=NanoTech Institute|publisher=ZYVEX|accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> and others who have achieved prominent careers in business, government, engineering, science, medicine, the arts and education.
